scenes.title: Three-front war for growth
scenes.main_point: AI raised expectations, collapsed distribution, and intensified competition.
scenes.scene_summary: AI raised customer expectations, collapsed channels, and put everyone after your value prop.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
A startup founder stands at a cluttered desk in a small office, facing three converging forces: a looming AI-shaped cloud, crumbling signposts labeled “SEO,” “Paid,” and “Social,” and shadowy figures of incumbents, startups, and customers reaching toward the same glowing value prop.
The founder looks tense as the room feels like a three-front war for growth.

scenes.title: A new playbook: Trust
scenes.main_point: Growth shifted to a trust-centered model.
scenes.scene_summary: A new growth playbook emerged, and it centered on one concept: trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same war-room from scene 1, the same startup team gathers around the strategy board as the chaotic arrows are replaced by a single clear path labeled “TRUST.”
They pause with a focused, hopeful calm as the new trust-centered growth model takes shape.

scenes.title: Sponsor: Cello referral platform
scenes.main_point: Cello automated referrals and affiliates for product-led growth.
scenes.scene_summary: Cello automated referrals, attribution, and rewards to drive predictable product-led growth.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
The same startup team from the previous scene stands around their desk, placing a small “Cello” placard beside a simple referral platform dashboard.
On the screen, affiliates, attribution paths, and reward icons auto-organize into a neat flow, and the team looks quietly reassured in the cozy office.

scenes.title: Classic acquisition channels deteriorated
scenes.main_point: Traditional distribution got more expensive and less efficient.
scenes.scene_summary: Marketing channels got pricier and weaker, and the trend kept getting worse.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room from the previous scene, the founder and a small team stare at a wall board of classic acquisition channels as arrows slope downward and cost numbers climb.
A printed “Andrew Chen” article is pinned beside the charts, and the team looks worried as they realize traditional distribution is getting pricier and less efficient.

scenes.title: SEO and search traffic broke
scenes.main_point: AI content and AI answers reduced organic search value.
scenes.scene_summary: AI slop flooded SEO, and AI answers intercepted clicks before users reached websites.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room, the same founder and small team stare at a laptop showing a search page where Google AI answers and ChatGPT/Claude/Perplexity summaries sit above their site.
A flood of identical AI-generated blog pages piles up on the table like paper, while a thin stream of clicks diverts away from their website dashboard, implying frustration.

scenes.title: Paid search economics collapsed
scenes.main_point: SEM costs rose while AI tools competed directly on value.
scenes.scene_summary: SEM bids spiked on flat search volume, while $20 AI tools replaced keyword-driven solutions.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same small startup office, the founder and marketer stare at a laptop showing skyrocketing SEM keyword bids and sinking ROAS charts.
On the desk beside them, a cheap $20 AI tool app on a phone replaces their keyword-driven solution, leaving them visibly worried.

scenes.title: Corporate social lost conversion power
scenes.main_point: Platforms deprioritized external links and punished corporate distribution.
scenes.scene_summary: Social platforms favored on-platform engagement, so corporate posts struggled to drive external traffic.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same small startup office, the founder and marketer stare at a wall monitor showing a social feed where corporate posts have their external links grayed out and buried by the algorithm.
They keep swapping new post drafts on a laptop in a weary creative treadmill, watching the outbound clicks counter barely move.

scenes.title: Trust-based acquisition channels worked
scenes.main_point: People trusted people: employees, creators, and communities.
scenes.scene_summary: Employee voices, creator partnerships, and communities transferred trust and fueled word of mouth.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup office from earlier scenes, the founder watches employees share authentic posts on their phones while a creator partner chats with them.
Nearby, a small community circle passes along handwritten recommendation notes, trust and excitement spreading as word of mouth grows.

scenes.title: Brand became a product job
scenes.main_point: Product experience created trust and differentiated beyond features.
scenes.scene_summary: Brand came from product experience, and every interaction either built or broke trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup office war-room, the founder and product designer refine a simple app interface on a large screen, polishing tiny UX details.
Around them, sticky notes labeled “trust signals” replace feature lists, conveying calm focus and determination.

scenes.title: AI weakened traditional retention value props
scenes.main_point: Cheaper/faster value props got commoditized by AI.
scenes.scene_summary: AI beat most SaaS on cost and speed, weakening efficiency-based retention.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room, the founder and small team watch a friendly AI spirit rapidly stamp “cheaper / faster / more effective” onto identical product cards, making their retention chart droop.
Whiteboard and sticky notes show “retention pressure” and “commoditized,” and the team looks worried.

scenes.title: Trust-based retention system
scenes.main_point: Retention depended on confidence the team would keep delivering outcomes.
scenes.scene_summary: Customers stayed when they trusted ongoing outcomes—roadmaps, fast iteration, WOW UX, aligned pricing.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room, the founder and team calmly update a transparent roadmap board while a few customers watch and nod, sticky-note feedback turning into freshly shipped feature cards.
A screen shows lifecycle messages and outcome-aligned pricing tiers beside a small “WOW” UX demo, conveying steady confidence.

scenes.title: Operational shift and urgent close
scenes.main_point: Trust-based growth required org alignment, velocity, and building in public.
scenes.scene_summary: Teams aligned, shipped fast, built in public, and treated trust as the compounding moat.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room from earlier scenes, the familiar cross-functional team (founder, engineer, marketer, designer) huddles around a wall of sticky notes and a live public changelog board, pushing out a final micro-release together.
On a side monitor, old channel graphs plunge while a “Trust” thread grows steadily; the team looks focused and resolved as alignment and velocity become their compounding moat.
